case_name: M/s. Bhajan Singh Hardat Singh and Co. v. Karson Agency India and another

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal under Clause 10 of the Letters Patent of the High Court of Punjab originally heard by Division Bench S.S. Dulat and S.K. Kapur JJ, referred to larger Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Tatachari, J. This letters patent appeal under Clause 10 of the Letters Patent of the High Court of Punjab originally came up for hearing before a Division Bench of the High Court  S.S. Dulat and S.K. Kapur, JJ . The learned Judges took the view that the case involved a question of limitation which should be decided by a larger Bench.

facts.text: Appellant Ms. Bhajan Singh Hardat Singh and Co. filed suit No. 718 of 1954 in Court of Shri Munnilal Jain, Sub-Judge 1st Class, Delhi, for recovery of Rs.3392/9/6 from respondents Karson Agency India and another.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, M s. Bhajan Singh Hardat Singh and Co., filed a suit No. 718 of 1954 in the Court of Shri Munnilal Jain, P.C. S., Sub-Judge, 1st Class, Delhi, for recovery of Rs.3392/9/6 from the respondents , herein Karson Agency  India  and another who were impleaded as defendants in the said suit.

facts.text: On 14-2-1951, respondents agreed at Delhi to purchase from appellant 500 yards of worsted woolen cloth of Indian Woolen Mills, steel colour, June-July Challan at Rs.23/4/- per yard and paid Rs.1,000/- advance.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant-plaintiff was That on 14-2-51, the respondents defendants agreed at Delhi to purchase from the appellant 500 Yards of worsted  Woolen cloth  of Indian Woolen Mills, steel companyour, June - July, Challan at Rs.23/4/ per yard and paid Rs.1,000/- as advance

facts.text: On 25-7-1951, appellant sent Bill Ex. P-10 No. 5306 to respondents for 500 yards, balance Rs.10,625/- after advance, required to take delivery by end of July 1951, but respondents did not take delivery.

anchor.surface_text: that on 25-7-1951, the respondents were sent a Bill  Ex. P-10  No. 5306, for 500 yards worsted as per the companytract, and were required to take delivery of the goods after payment of Rs.10,625/- which was the balance amount due after deducting the advance of Rs.1,000/- from the total amount of Rs.11,625/-, the price of the cloth as per the companytract, and that the respondents were asked to take delivery by the end of July, 1951, but that they did number take delivery of the goods.

facts.text: On 6-8-1951, appellant sent registered notice Ex. P-7 to respondents to take delivery within 4 days against payment of Rs.10,625/-, failing which goods would be sold at their risk; respondents did not take delivery.

anchor.surface_text: Again, on 6-81951, the appellant-plaintiff sent a registered numberice  Ex. P-7  to the respondents defendants informing them that they should take delivery within 4 days, failing which the goods would be sold at the risk and the responsibility of the respondents defendants.

facts.text: Appellant sold the goods on retail basis on 8-11-1951, 9-11-1951, 10-11-1951, 15-11-1951, 16-11-1951 and 20-11-1951 at market rates, realized Rs.7,349/1/9.

anchor.surface_text: that the appellant, therefore, sold the goods, on retail basis, on 8-11-1951, 9-11-1951, 10-11-1951, 15-11-9151, 16-11-1951 and 20-11-1951, at the market rates which prevailed on the said rates, that the amount realised from the sale was Rs. 7,349/1/9,

facts.text: Loss on resale Rs.4,392/9/6, after adjusting advance Rs.1,000/-, balance Rs.3,392/9/6 not paid despite demands.

anchor.surface_text: that the amount realised from the sale was Rs. 7,349/1/9, that the appellant thus suffered a loss of Rs. 4,392/9/6 on the re-sale of the goods, that after adjusting the advance amount of Rs.1,000/-, the balance due was Rs. 3,3,92/9/6 which the respondents did number pay in spite of repeated demands,

facts.text: Suit filed on 19-11-1954 for Rs.3,392/9/6 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: and that, therefore, the suit was filed on 19-11-1954, for recovery of the said amount of Rs. 3,392/9/6, with future interest at 10 annas per cent per mensem from the date of decree till the realisation of the decretal amount.

facts.text: Respondents contended suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents- defendants companyntered, inter alia, that the suit was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Trial Court (Sub-Judge) by judgment dated 1-11-1955 held suit within time, decreed in favor of plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: the learned Subordinate Judge, by his judgment dated 1-11-55, held all the issues including the issue No. 2 regarding limitation in favour of the appellant-plaintiff, and decreed the suit as prayed for.

facts.text: Appeal No. 43 of 1956 to Additional District Judge Shri P.D. Sharma, Delhi, judgment 8/9-4-1957 affirmed trial court on limitation, dismissed appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against that judgment and decree, the respondents - defendants preferred an appeal No. 43 of 1956 to the Court of Shri P.D. Sharma, Additional District Judge, Delhi. The learned District Judge, by his judgment dated 8/9-4-1957, affirmed the finding of the trial Court that the suit was number barred by limitation,

facts.text: Regular Second Appeal No. 93-D of 1957 to Circuit Bench High Court of Punjab, heard by Falshaw C.J., judgment 17-1-1962 allowed appeal, dismissed suit as barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: Against that judgment and decree, the respondents - defendants preferred Regular Second Appeal No. 93-D of 1957, to the Circuit Bench of the High Court of Punjab. The Second Appeal was heard by Falshaw , C.J., who by his judgment dated 17-1-1962 allowed the Second Appeal, set aside the judgments and the decrees of the lower Courts, and dismissed the suit on the ground that it was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Property in goods did not pass to buyer as goods unascertained and no unconditional appropriation.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, numbere of these requirements is satisfied. Ex. P-7 read with Ex. P-10 clearly shows that there was numberseparation or ascertainment of specific 500 yards from the bales.

facts.text: No right of resale under Section 54(2) Sale of Goods Act as property had not passed to buyer.

anchor.surface_text: If the property in the goods did number pass to the buyer there can be numberquestion of the seller having any right to resell by virtue of the provisions in Section 46 1  and 54 2  of the Sale of Goods Act.

facts.text: Suit is for compensation for breach of contract, governed by Article 115 Limitation Act, limitation runs from end of July 1951 when breach occurred by refusal to take delivery.

anchor.surface_text: that Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies to the said suit, that the period of limitation of three years prescribed by Article 115 companymenced to run from the said date of the breach of the companytract, and that the suit filed by the appellant-plaintiff on 19-11-1954 was barred by limitation.

facts.text: Goods were to be delivered in June or July 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The said goods were to be delivered in June or July 1951.

facts.text: Contract price Rs.11,625/- for 500 yards.

anchor.surface_text: The companytract price was Rs.11,625, and the amount got by resale was short by Rs.4392-9-6.

facts.text: Resale realized Rs.7349-1-9.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant-plaintiff resold the goods at Delhi at the prevailing rates on retail basis between 8-11-1951 and 20-11-1951 for a total sum of Rs. 7349-1-9.

facts.text: Suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: and that the suit filed by the appellant-plaintiff on 19-11-1954 was barred by limitation.

arguments.claim: Goods not perishable under S.54(2) SOGA

anchor.surface_text: We consider it difficult to accept the submission of the learned counsel that they can be regarded as perishable goods within the meaning of Section 54(2).

arguments.claim: S.24 Limitation Act does not apply; breach itself cause of action

anchor.surface_text: There is clearly no basis for the argument of Shri Anoop Singh placing reliance upon Section 24 of the Limitation Act. The said section contemplates the case of a suit for compensation for an act which does not give rise to a cause of action.

arguments.claim: S.46(2) SOGA gives withholding delivery but not resale if property not passed

anchor.surface_text: Section 46(2) on the other hand declares the rights of an unpaid seller where property in the goods has not passed to the buyer but remained in the seller... a right of withholding delivery similar to and co-extensive with his right of lien and stoppage in transit where the property has passed to the buyer.

arguments.claim: Eastern Traders case obiter on S.24; not applicable

anchor.surface_text: The decision should, therefore, be regarded as confined to the facts of that particular case, and not as laying down a general proposition of law regarding the scope and applicability of Section 24 of the Limitation Act.

arguments.claim: Precedents support Art.115 from breach date, not postponed to damage quantification

anchor.surface_text: In [cases], it was held that a claim for loss sustained by a party after resale... ought to be instituted within three years of the date of the breach of the contract that Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies... the occasion for ascertainment will have to be distinguished from the date upon which the cause of action arose

arguments.claim: Suit treated as shortfall recovery assumes 3 yr limitation from resale but actually compensation for breach under Art.115

anchor.surface_text: Thus the trial Court treated the suit as one for recovery of the shortfall and not as one for compensation for breach of the contract, and assumed that the period of limitation is three years (presumably under Article 115) and that the said period of limitation commenced to run from the date of the resale.

holdings.text: The suit filed by the appellant-plaintiff on 19-11-1954 was barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: and that the suit filed by the appellant-plaintiff on 19-11-1954 was barred by limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit for compensation for breach governed by Art.115 Limitation Act; 3-year period runs from breach date (end July 1951) when respondents refused delivery; filed after 3 years.

holdings.text: Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies to the suit for compensation for the breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies to the suit, and as provided in that Article, limitation began to run from the date on which the breach of the contract was committed by the respondents-defendants i.e. from the end of July, 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit is prima facie for compensation for breach, quantified as resale shortfall; specific Art.115 governs over residuary Art.120.

holdings.text: Limitation under Article 115 commenced to run from the end of July 1951, the date of the breach.

anchor.surface_text: As such, Article 115 of the Limitation Act applies to the suit, and as provided in that Article, limitation began to run from the date on which the breach of the contract was committed by the respondents-defendants i.e. from the end of July, 1951.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Breach occurred when respondents refused to take delivery by end July; ascertainment of damages on resale does not postpone starting point; supported by precedents distinguishing cause from quantification.

holdings.text: Property in the goods did not pass to the buyer.

anchor.surface_text: If the property in the goods did not pass to the buyer there can be no question of the seller having any right to resell by virtue of the provisions in Section 46(1) and 54(2) of the Sale of Goods Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods unascertained; no separation of 500 yards from bales; no unconditional appropriation with buyer assent per S.23 SOGA.

holdings.text: There was no unconditional appropriation of the specific 500 yards to the contract.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, none of these requirements is satisfied. Ex. P-7 read with Ex. P-10 clearly shows that there was no separation or ascertainment of specific 500 yards from the bales.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ex.P-10 and P-7 show goods not separated/ascertained; appropriation conditional on payment; no buyer assent; requirements of S.18,23 SOGA not met.

holdings.text: The unpaid seller had no right to resell under Sections 46(1)(c) and 54(2) of the Sale of Goods Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 46(1) describes the rights of an unpaid seller against the goods after they have become the property of the buyer... If the property in the goods did not pass to the buyer there can be no question of the seller having any right to resell by virtue of the provisions in Section 46(1) and 54(2) of the Sale of Goods Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resale right under S.46(1)(c)/S.54(2) only where property passed to buyer; here property remained with seller, only withholding delivery under S.46(2).

holdings.text: The goods (worsted woolen cloth) were not perishable goods within the meaning of Section 54(2) SOGA.

anchor.surface_text: We consider it difficult to accept the submission of the learned counsel that they can be regarded as perishable goods within the meaning of Section 54(2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: No definition; even broadly (deterioration or rapid price fall), no evidence of such for woolen cloth.

holdings.text: Section 24 of the Limitation Act does not apply to postpone limitation.

anchor.surface_text: There is clearly no basis for the argument of Shri Anoop Singh placing reliance upon Section 24 of the Limitation Act. The said section contemplates the case of a suit for compensation for an act which does not give rise to a cause of action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.24 for acts not immediately giving cause; here refusal to take delivery immediately breached contract and gave cause for compensation.

holdings.text: Ascertainment of damages is distinct from the cause of action, which arises on breach.

anchor.surface_text: the ascertainment of the amount to be claimed in a suit for damages for the breach of a contract is something separate and distinct from the occasion of such ascertainment, which is the real cause of action.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resale may quantify damages but does not create cause; limitation from breach per Art.115; affirmed by precedents like Soundara Rajan.

holdings.text: Observations in Eastern Traders on S.24 Limitation Act are obiter dicta.

anchor.surface_text: The decision should, therefore, be regarded as confined to the facts of that particular case, and not as laying down a general proposition of law regarding the scope and applicability of Section 24 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No detailed discussion; decision on lack of proof of damages, not limitation; confined to facts.

precedents.citation: Soundara Rajan and Co., v. K.P.A.T. Annamalai Nadar,

anchor.surface_text: Soundara Rajan and Co., v. K.P.A.T. Annamalai Nadar,

precedents.case_name: Soundara Rajan and Co v K.P.A.T. Annamalai Nadar
precedents.cited_proposition: under Article 115 of the Limitation Act the starting point of the limitation is the date on which the defendants refused or failed to take delivery of the goods tendered to them within the time specified in the contract

precedents.citation: Maclean v. Dunn  1828  4 Bing 722 at pp. 728-729 29 R.R. 714

anchor.surface_text: Maclean v. Dunn  1828  4 Bing 722 at pp. 728-729 29 R.R. 714. It is doubtful, however whether this meaning should be given to the word perishable but suggestion is worthy of notice

precedents.cited_proposition: goods are perishable if their price is liable to fall rapidly

precedents.citation: In the matter of David Sassoon and Co. Ltd. Air 1926 Sind 246  247

anchor.surface_text: In the matter of David Sassoon and Co. Ltd. Air 1926 Sind 246  247  the goods were specially appropriated to the buyers by certain running numbers which were specified in the Invoices and in the Arrival notices.

precedents.case_name: In re David Sassoon and Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: goods specially appropriated to the buyers by certain running numbers specified in the invoices and arrival notices held appropriated by the sellers as the goods of the buyers
precedents.cited_holding: goods were appropriated by the sellers as the goods of the buyers

precedents.citation: Firm Paharia Mal Ram Sahai v. Birdhi Chand Jain and Sons,

anchor.surface_text: Firm Paharia Mal Ram Sahai v. Birdhi Chand Jain and Sons, , it was held that where there is a contract for the sale of unascertained goods and the goods are deliverable to the buyer ex-godown at place A,

precedents.case_name: Firm Paharia Mal Ram Sahai v Birdhi Chand Jain and Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: where there is a contract for the sale of unascertained goods and the goods are deliverable to the buyer ex-godown at place A then if the buyer at B instructs the seller by letter to send the goods by lorry the buyer must be held to have impliedly assented to the appropriation made by the seller when he removed the goods from his godown

precedents.citation: Commr. Of Income-Tax, Madras v. Mysore Chromite Ltd.,

anchor.surface_text: Commr. Of Income-Tax, Madras v. Mysore Chromite Ltd., , the contract was for the sale of chrome ores [...] the requirement of Section 23 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act is not only that there shall be appropriation of the goods to the contract

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Madras v Mysore Chromite Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: appropriation must be unconditional; merely placing goods on slip not unconditional appropriation if payment required before documents released
precedents.cited_holding: property passed outside India when payment made

precedents.citation: M s. Carona Sahu Co.  P  Ltd. V. State of Maharashtra,

precedents.case_name: Carona Sahu Co Pvt Ltd v State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: in case of contract for sale of unascertained goods property does not pass unless unconditional appropriation of goods in deliverable state to contract; delivery to common carrier sufficient appropriation

anchor.surface_text: In re Wait,  1927 , 1 Ch 606, by a C.I.F. contract [...] held by the Court of Appeal that the 500 tons were not specific or ascertained goods and that there never was any such appropriation or identification

precedents.cited_proposition: no appropriation or identification of specific goods in bulk shipment under C.I.F. contract giving sub-purchasers beneficial interest
precedents.cited_holding: 500 tons not specific or ascertained no equitable assignment

precedents.cited_proposition: breach not sufficient cause of action until injury sustained when goods disposed of; time runs from that date per Section 24 Limitation Act

edges.explanation: The issue is addressed by the holding's determination of no unconditional appropriation.
Resolving whether goods are perishable requires determining the applicable concept of perishable goods, particularly for non-obvious items like worsted woolen cloth.

Precedent Maclean v Dunn establishes the test for perishable goods as those whose price is liable to fall rapidly, which c14 directly references by noting no evidence of rapid price fall for worsted woolen cloth.
Precedent provides definitional support for assessing the issue of perishability under Section 54(2).

Precedent requiring unconditional appropriation supports S.23
Precedent on lack of unconditional appropriation supports holding of no such appropriation
Precedent supports argument property does not pass for unascertained goods
Precedent that property does not pass for unascertained without conditions supports S.23
